candidates.title: Fix(receive): Handle sleds of identical RTP timestamps

labels.name: driver
labels.description: Relates to the driver or one of its sub-tasks.

labels.name: fix
labels.description: Fixes a bug or error

labels.name: receive
labels.description: Related to voice receive, decoding, decryption, or events

candidates.body:
Bots joining calls with users seem to provoke large runs of packets with identical timestamps -- the existing logic was intended to handle this catchup case in addition to the normal (+=960) at all times.

However, we were checking that a packet was modulo greater-than the next ts, rather than modulo less-than. Simple enough to fix.

candidates.title: fix(dependecies): don't use default features for stream_lib
candidates.body:
stream_lib would always pull in native-tls, this was changed in 0.4.2
which contains a backport of https://github.com/Erk-/rsget/pull/45.

candidates.title: feat(input): Support HLS streams
candidates.body:
I am not quite sure about saying that it is lazy, because it eagerly downloads the stream. And thus it can also be used for livestreams. But it fits better into the Lazy Input type imo.

Closes: #241

candidates.title: Driver: Support `tokio-websockets`
candidates.body: Allows for configuring the crate to use [`tokio-websockets`](https://crates.io/crates/tokio-websockets) instead of `tokio-tungstenite` since Twilight 0.16 [is switching to TWS](https://github.com/twilight-rs/twilight/blob/main/book/src/versions/0.16/summary.md#switch-to-tokio-websockets-and-fastrand).

candidates.title: Remove typemap from songbird
candidates.body: Split off from #218, removes typemap from songbird by using a dyn Any instead. This is already the approach taken for user data in serenity:next.

candidates.title: Fix serenity next breaking
candidates.body:
Blocked on #219.

Serenity has made a switch from NonZero to NonMax for IDs, as it allows the cool niche opts without causing collisions with buggy discord code leading to this. We need to swap over to this.

Serenity has also reworked the state system, to remove typemap, so I fixed the examples.

candidates.title: Allow borrowed strings for YoutubeDl
candidates.body:
This changes `YoutubeDl` to have a lifetime, to allow users to provide `&str` references for the url/query. This can't currently be used for `Input`, where users have to provide `String` or `&'static str`, but is useful for users fetching metadata/searching.

This also makes `search` return `impl Iterator` to avoid the unnecessary `Vec` buffering possibly performed, which relies on `Either` as a primitive form of `enum_dispatch`, but it's already in the dep tree so it doesn't matter.

candidates.title: Driver: Implement audio scheduler

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: driver
labels.description: Relates to the driver or one of its sub-tasks.

candidates.body:
This PR introduces a scheduler for audio threads: idle tasks are all run on a single background async task, while live audio threads are grouped up into full sync threads. Tasks are dynamically promoted and demoted based on whether they have any live audio tracks. This adds in some other niceties like preventing packet buffer reallocations, where possible. I intend to add reclamation of packet buffers, worker threads, and offloading expensive tasks to other threads.

This defaults to grouping 16 live calls per thread, mainly to prevent issues with users not compiling in release mode and/or using weaker machines. This can be configured during `Config` creation, and should be tuned for users at scale -- for instance, a passthrough-only workload can serve up to ~660 calls per thread on a Ryzen 5700X.

To put this in context, if all calls are live, this defaults to a 16x reduction in the amount of threads used. If only 30% of calls are live, the remainder all go in a single async task, giving an asymptotic 53x reduction of thread count.

TODO:
- [x] Cleanup & document the draft implementation
- [x] Fix Benchmarks to account for scheduler
- [x] Integrate testing of scheduler behaviours into harness
- [x] Periodically reclaim threads and packet blocks
- [x] Update ARCHITECTURE.md

candidates.title: Twilight 0.15 support
candidates.body:
This patch changes around quite a few things.
The main entry point for twilight besides `process` will now be the
`TwilightMap` which consists of command senders for each shard.

This simplifies parts of the code as there is not any difference
between shards and clusters anymore.

candidates.title: Driver/receive: Implement audio reorder/jitter buffer

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: driver
labels.description: Relates to the driver or one of its sub-tasks.

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: Will either cause existing code to fail to compile, or cause substantial behaviour changes

labels.name: receive
labels.description: Related to voice receive, decoding, decryption, or events

candidates.body:
This PR Introduces a new `VoiceTick` event which collects and reorders all RTP packets to smooth over network instability, as well as to synchronise user audio streams. Raw packet events have been moved to `RtpPacket`, while `SpeakingUpdate`s have been removed as they can be easily computed using the `silent`/`speaking` audio maps included in each event.

Closes #146.

candidates.title: Input: Fix audio stream selection for video files.

labels.name: driver
labels.description: Relates to the driver or one of its sub-tasks.

labels.name: input
labels.description: Relates to raw audio data handling.

labels.name: fix
labels.description: Fixes a bug or error

candidates.body:
`youtube-dl` has a tendency to return mp4 files containing video and audio data vs `yt-dlp`. Naturally, the default stream in such cases will be the video data, so we fail to create a decoder.

This PR changes `LiveInput::promote` to first attempt to instantiate a decoder for the default track. If this fails to do so, then we reattempt this for all available tracks until one can be found. Previously, this method chose the default (or first available) track ID, and then failed if *that* track could not be decoded even if a compatible stream existed.

This was tested using `cargo make ready`, as well as manually verifying and adding a test case with a simple mp4 file.

milestone.title: v0.4.0: Nightingale
milestone.description: Bigger changes to songbird, including an overhaul of the internal audio stack towards Symphonia.

candidates.body:
Adds the "receive" feature, which is disabled by default. When this is disabled, the UDP receive task is not compiled and not run, and as an optimisation the UDP receive buffer size is set to 0. All related events are also removed.

Closes #131.

candidates.title: Chore: Rework crate features

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: Will either cause existing code to fail to compile, or cause substantial behaviour changes

candidates.body:
All dependencies have been moved to the new "dep:x" and "x?/feature" syntax to remove the bloat from the docs.rs/crates.io/lib.rs feature panes.

Accordingly, this lets us break "rustls" and "native" out from annoying hybrids like "serenity-rustls" or "twilight-native" -- specify your library and your bacnend, and it should just work.

The complete list of features is now: driver, gateway, serenity, twilight, rustls, native, builtin-queue, simd-json, internals (plus "default" and "full-doc").

candidates.title: Driver/Input: Migrate audio backend to Symphonia

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: input
labels.description: Relates to raw audio data handling.

labels.name: tracks
labels.description: Relates to audio control, state, or lifecycle management.

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: Will either cause existing code to fail to compile, or cause substantial behaviour changes

candidates.body:
This begins work on #67, which will be a huge step towards purely in-process audio processing (i.e., one day eliminating ffmpeg).

- [x] Audiopus-based Symphonia codec and DCA1 framing.
- [x] Ensure that Opus packet passthrough can be performed through Symphonia.
- [x] Port mixing infrastructure (and packet passthrough).
- [x] Rework `input` interface.
- [x] Implement basic DASH handling for youtube and other multimedia handlers extracted from youtube-dl.
- [ ] Investigate upstreaming MKV support to Symphonia.
- [x] Port our stream-cacheing wrappers to this ecosystem.

There will be some slight issues stemming from the fact that we will now be parsing metadata from bytestreams as they arrive:
* How will metadata be accessible to users before it enters the mixer? Is this just a `spawn_blocking` on the initial `Format` parse phase? Pass messages out from the main mixer context?
* Users will need to be able to both pass in raw `MediaSourceStream`s, `Read`s, *and* fully processed `(Format, Metadata, ...)` sets -- due to the above, and as some extra metadata will *only* be exposed by youtube-dl, for instance.
* Until MKV support is impl'd, we'll probably need to peek at bytes internally and pass over to ffmpeg on a decode failure. Having such a fallback should probably be toggleable.
* We'll probably need to offer one or two wrappers to hand over `AsyncRead`s into the mixing system (as well as automating extension/MIME type extraction from `File`s or HTTP responses).
